thread.title_full: Kantar Worldpanel ComTech shows Aussies leading the world in ditching Android for Apple iPhone | Technology | Tech News and Latest New Technology | | dailytelegraph.com.au

author: dailytelegraph.com
title: Kantar Worldpanel ComTech shows Aussies leading the world in ditching Android for Apple iPhone | Technology | Tech News and Latest New Technology | | dailytelegraph.com.au
text:
DESPITE Samsung hitting the market first with its new flagship smartphone, Australians have continued to turn away from Android and switch to Apple.
Kantar Worldpanel ComTech today has released its smartphone sales data for the quarter ending July which shows a swing from Android to Apple of more than 18 percentage points.
The Android share in the Australian market dropped 10.5 points, from 66.6 per cent to 56.1, while the iOS share jumped 7.9 points from 27 to 34.9.
That put Australia as the number one market in terms of growth of marketshare for the Apple iPhone.
The immediate outlook for Android is not good, with Apple expected to announce two new iPhones (the iPhone 6S and 6S Plus) next week in a move that is set to ignite a new sales spike for Apple.
Launch date: What to expect in the iPhone 6S
The iPhone . still on top. Picture: iStock Source: Supplied
Miley Cyrus held a Samsung phone at the 2015 MTV Video Music Awards earlier this week. Picture: Kevork Djansezian/Getty Images Source: Getty Images
The iPhone 6 still holds the number one position on the list of top selling models, even though many Apple fans traditionally hold off on buying a new iPhone in the lead up to the release of the new model this month.
The good news for Samsung is that it has four phones in the top 10, although last year’s Galaxy S5 still remains a bigger seller than this year’s Galaxy S6.
On a global level, Android OS continued to show market share losses in China, Japan and in Europe’s big five markets of Great Britain, Germany, France, Italy and Spain, although it picked up 1.7 percentage points in the United States.
The switch from operating systems showed the same pattern. Across Europe, 27 per cent of smartphone buyers traded in an Android phone for an iPhone, while in the US it was just 9 per cent making the switch.
Apple and Samsung remain the two power players in the smartphone wars. In the US, nine out of 10 smartphones sold for the quarter were either an Apple or Samsung.
